item.title: Exodus 1
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 1

1Israel’s descendants and their households that went to Egypt with Jacob: 2Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, 3Issachar, Zebulun, Benjamin, 4Dan, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher: 570 people (though Joseph was already there)

6That whole generation died, 7but Israel’s descendants multiplied and became so numerous they filled the country.

Ex 1:1-7

The Israelites Oppressed

8In time, a new king came to power in Egypt who didn’t know Joseph. 9He told his people, “There are too many Israelites, and they’re too strong. 10Let’s deal with them wisely so, if there’s war, they won’t join our enemies and leave.” 11They appointed taskmasters and subjected the Israelites to hard labor. They built storage cities for Pharaoh: Pithom and Raamses. 12But the more they mistreated them, the more they multiplied and spread. The Egyptians were afraid of them [13] 14and made their lives miserable, making bricks and mortar and laboring in the fields. Ex 1:8-14

item.title: Exodus 2
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 2

1A descendant from Levi married a woman from Levi, 2and she had a son. When she saw he was such a handsome baby, she hid him for three months. 3When she couldn’t hide him anymore, she got a papyrus reed basket and covered it with tar. She put him in it and set it in the reeds by the bank of the Nile. 4His sister stood a distance away to see what would happen to him. 5Pharaoh’s daughter came down to bathe at the Nile with her attendants. As she walked along the river, she saw the basket in the reeds and had her maid bring it to her.

item.title: Exodus 3
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 3

1Moses was pasturing Jethro’s/Reuel’s flock and led it to the west side of the open country around Horeb/Sinai, the mountain of God. 2The angel of the LORD appeared to him in a blazing bush. Moses looked up and saw the bush on fire, but it didn’t burn up. 3He said, “I have to go over and see this curious thing. Why isn’t it burning up?” 4When the LORD saw him coming to look, he called from the bush, “Moses!” “Yes?” 5“Don’t come any closer. Take your sandals off. You’re standing on sacred ground. 6I’m the God of your ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.” Moses hid his face, afraid to look at God. 7“I’ve seen my people’s suffering in Egypt and paid attention to their outcry because of the taskmasters. 8I’ve come down to deliver them and bring them out to a good land with lots of room, a land flowing with milk and honey, the territory of the Canaanite, Hittite, Amorite, Perizzite, Hivite, and Jebusite. 9I’ve seen how the Egyptians are oppressing them. 10Go; I’ll send you to Pharaoh so you can bring my people out of Egypt.” 11“Why me?” 12“I’ll be with you. This will be the sign that I’ve sent you: when you’ve brought them out, you’ll worship me at this mountain.”

item.title: Exodus 4
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 4

1Moses answered, “What if they don’t believe me, ‘The LORD hasn’t really appeared to you!’?” 2“What’s in your hand?” “A staff.” 3“Throw it on the ground.” He threw it on the ground, and it became a snake. Moses jumped back.

4But the LORD said, “Grab its tail.” He caught it, and it turned back into a staff in his hand. 5“They’ll believe that the LORD God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob has appeared to you. 6Put your hand into your chest.” He did; when he took it out, it was leprous like snow. 7“Put it in again.” He did, and it became like the rest of him. 8“If the first sign doesn’t convince them, the second may. 9If neither one does, dip some water out of the Nile and pour it on dry ground. It’ll become blood.”

item.title: Exodus 5
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 5

1After that, Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh, “The LORD, Israel’s God, says to let his people go so they can celebrate a festival to him in the open country.”

2Pharaoh said, “Who is the LORD that I should obey him? I don’t know him. I’m not going to let them go.”

3They said, “The God of the Hebrews has met with us. Let us go a three-day’s journey into open country to sacrifice to the LORD our God so he won’t fall on us with disease or sword.”

item.title: Exodus 6
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 6

1The LORD told Moses, “Now you’ll see what I’ll do to Pharaoh. He’ll have to let them go. I’ll make him send them out of his country. 2I’m Yahveh. 3I appeared to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob as ‘God Almighty’ [El-Shaddai]. I didn’t make myself known to them by my name ‘Yahveh.’ 4I made a covenant with them to give them Canaan, where they were living as nomads. 5I’ve heard the Israelites’ groaning because the Egyptians are holding them in slavery, and I’ve remembered my covenant. 6Tell the Israelites, ‘I’ll take you out from under Egyptian bondage and redeem you with power and great acts of judgment. 7I’ll take you to be my people and be your God. You’ll know I’m the LORD your God who brought you out from under the burdens the Egyptians put on you. 8I’ll take you to the land I swore to give Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.’”

item.title: Exodus 7
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 7

1The LORD told him, “I’m making you like God to him, and your brother Aaron will be your prophet. 2Say what I tell you, and Aaron will tell Pharaoh to let Israel leave his country. 3But I’ll harden his heart so I can multiply my signs and wonders. 4When he won’t listen to you, I’ll lay my hand on Egypt and take out my people with tremendous acts of judgment. 5The Egyptians will know I’m the LORD.”

item.title: Exodus 8
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 8

1The LORD said to Moses, “Go tell Pharaoh the LORD says to let his people go so they can serve him. 2If you don’t, he’ll strike the whole country with frogs. 3The Nile will teem with them. They’ll come up into your house, your bedroom, your bed, your officials’ houses and on your people, in your ovens and kneading bowls. [4]’”

5Then the LORD said to Moses, “Tell Aaron to hold his staff out over the rivers, canals, and pools, and make frogs come up all over the ground.” 6Aaron held his hand out over the water, and frogs came up and covered the whole country. 7The magicians did the same thing with their magic, and made frogs come up on the ground everywhere in Egypt.

item.title: Exodus 9
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 9

1The LORD told Moses, “Go tell Pharaoh, ‘The LORD God of the Hebrews says to let his people go so they can serve him. 2If you keep holding them, 3he’ll bring a severe plague on your livestock in the pasture—horses, donkeys, camels, herds, and flocks. 4But he’ll distinguish Israel’s livestock from Egypt’s. Nothing will die that belongs to the Israelites.’”

5The LORD set a time, “I’ll do that in the country tomorrow.” 6The next day he did it. Livestock in Egypt died, but none of the Israelites’ livestock died. 7Pharaoh sent to find out that not a one of the Israelites’ livestock died, but he hardened his heart and wouldn’t let the people go.

item.title: Exodus 10
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 10

1Then the LORD told Moses, “Go to Pharaoh; I’ve hardened his and his officers’ hearts so I can perform these signs among them 2and you can tell your sons and grandsons how I mocked the Egyptians with my signs, and so you can know I’m the LORD.”

3 3Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh, “The LORD God of the Hebrews says, ‘How long will you refuse to humble yourself toward me? Let my people go so they can serve me. 4If you don’t, I’ll bring locusts to your realm tomorrow. 5They’ll cover the ground so thick you can’t see it. They’ll eat what the hail didn’t ruin, every tree that sprouts in your field. 6Your houses, your officers’ houses, every Egyptian’s house will be full of them—something your fathers and grandfathers have never seen.’” He turned and left. 7Pharaoh’s officials said, “How long will that man hold us hostage? Let the men go so they can serve the LORD their God. Can’t you see that Egypt’s destroyed?”

item.title: Exodus 11
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 11

1The LORD told Moses, “I’m going to bring one more plague on Pharaoh and Egypt. After that, he’ll let you go. When he does, he’ll drive you out completely. 2Tell each man and woman to ask their neighbors for silver and gold articles.”

3The LORD gave the Egyptians a favorable attitude toward the people. Furthermore, Pharaoh’s officers and the people in general respected Moses a lot.

item.title: Exodus 12
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 12

1The LORD told Moses and Aaron, 2“This month will be the first month of your year. 3Tell the assembly of Israel that on the tenth of this month, each family is to take a lamb according to their families. 4If a family is too small for a lamb, that family and a nearby neighbor can take a lamb the size the number of people can eat. 5It needs to be an unblemished male a year old. Take it from the sheep or goats. 6Keep it till the fourteenth of the month. “The whole community is to kill it in the evening. 7Put some of its blood on the doorposts and lintel of the house where you eat it. 8Eat the meat that same night, roasted with fire. Eat it with bitter herbs and bread without yeast. 9Don’t eat any of it raw or boiled. Roast the head, legs, and entrails. 10In the morning, burn what’s left over. 11Eat it in a hurry, dressed, with sandals on your feet and staff in hand. It’s the LORD’s Passover. 12I’ll go all over Egypt that night and strike down the firstborn people and animals. I’ll execute judgment on Egypt’s gods. I’m the LORD. 13The blood on your houses will be a sign. When I see it, I’ll ‘pass over’ you. No plague will fall on you when I strike Egypt.

item.title: Exodus 13
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 13

1The LORD told Moses, 2“Set aside every firstborn human and animal.”

3Moses told the people, “Think back to today to when you came out of slavery in Egypt. With a strong hand the LORD took you out of here. Don’t eat anything with yeast in it. 4Today in the month Abib, you’re about to leave. 5When the LORD takes you to the territory of the Canaanite, Hittite, Amorite, Hivite, and Jebusite—the land he swore to your ancestors he’d give you, a land flowing with milk and honey—observe this rite in this month. 6Eat bread without yeast for a week. The seventh day, observe a feast to the LORD. 7Don’t have anything with yeast in it among you or in your territory. 8Tell your son that day, ‘It’s because of what the LORD did for me when I came out of Egypt.’ 9It will serve as a sign to you on your hand, a reminder on your forehead, that the Law of the LORD may be in your mouth, because he brought you out with a tremendous demonstration of power. 10Keep this ordinance every year at its scheduled time.

item.title: Exodus 14
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 14

1The LORD said to Moses, 2“Tell the Israelites to turn around and camp at Pi-hahiroth, between Migdol and the sea across from Baal-zephon. 3Pharaoh will say you’re wandering aimlessly; the open country has boxed you in. 4That’s how I’ll harden his heart, and he’ll chase you. He and his army will honor me, and the Egyptians will know I’m the LORD.” That’s what they did.

5When the king found out they’d left, he and his officials changed their minds, “What have we done, letting them leave from serving us?” 6He got his chariot ready and took his troops: 7600 select chariots as well as all the rest of Egypt’s chariots and their officers. 8As the Israelites were leaving boldly, 9the Egyptians chased them with Pharaoh’s horses, chariots, cavalry, and troops. They caught up with them camping by the sea beside Pi-hahiroth across from Baal-zephon.

item.title: Exodus 15
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 15

1Then Moses and the Israelites sang this song to the LORD: “I’ll sing to the LORD because he’s triumphed gloriously; he’s thrown the horse and its rider into the sea.

2The LORD is my strength and song; he is my salvation. He’s my God, and I’ll praise him, my ancestors’ God, and I’ll honor him.

3He’s a soldier; his name is the LORD.

item.title: Exodus 16
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 16

1The fifteenth day, second month after they left Egypt, they went from Elim to the Wilderness of Sin, between Elim and Sinai, 2They criticized Moses and Aaron in the desert, 3“If only the LORD had killed us in Egypt when we sat by pots of meat and ate bread till we were full. You’ve brought us out to this empty place to starve to death.”

Ex 16:1-3

item.title: Exodus 17
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 17

1Then the LORD told the community to travel from the Wilderness of Sin and camp at Rephidim. They didn’t have any water and 2complained to Moses, “Give us some water.” “Why are you complaining to me and testing the LORD?”

3But they were thirsty, “Why bring us up from Egypt to let us, our little ones, and our livestock die from thirst?”

4Moses called out to the LORD, “What am I going to do with them? They’re about ready to stone me.” 5“Go stand in front of them. Take some of the elders and the staff you used to strike the Nile. 6I’ll stand in front of you on the rock at Horeb/Sinai. Strike the rock, and water will come out of it for them to drink.” Moses did that. 7He named the place Massah and Meribah, because the Israelites “quarreled” with him and put the LORD on trial, “Is the LORD among us or not?”

item.title: Exodus 18
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 18

1Jethro/Reuel, priest in Midian, Moses’ father-in-law, heard what all God had done for Moses and his people in bringing them out of Egypt. 2He’d taken Moses’ wife Zipporah after Moses sent her away 3with her two sons Gershom (because he said, “I’ve been a ‘foreigner’ in a foreign land”) 4and Eliezer (because he said, “My father’s ‘God helped’ me and delivered me from Pharaoh’s sword”). 5-6Jethro/Reuel came to Moses with his wife and two sons, where Moses camped at the mountain of God. He sent word that he was bringing them. 7Moses went out to meet him, bowed and kissed him. They asked each other how they were doing and went into the tent. 8Moses told him what all the LORD had done to Pharaoh and the Egyptians for Israel’s sake, the hardships they’d had on the journey, and how the LORD had delivered them. 9Jethro/Reuel was overjoyed at the LORD’s goodness to Israel. 10He said, “Bless the LORD that delivered you from Pharaoh and the Egyptians’ control. 11Now I know he’s greater than all other gods. He proved it when they dealt arrogantly against the people.”

item.title: Exodus 19
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 19

1The same day of the third month after Israel left Egypt, they came to the Wilderness of Sinai. 2They’d set out from Rephidim and came to camp at the mountain. 3Moses went up to God, and the LORD called to him from the mountain, “Tell Jacob’s house, 4‘You’vepl seen what I did to the Egyptians, how I carried you on eagles’ wings and brought you to me. 5If you’ll obey me and keep my covenant, you’ll be my special possession among the nations. The whole world belongs to me, 6but you’ll be a kingdom of priests, a holy nation.’”

item.title: Exodus 20
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 20

1Then God spoke,

2I am the LORD your God who brought you out of slavery in Egypt.

3Do not havef any god but me.

4Do not makef any carved image, any likeness of what is in the sky, on the ground, or in the water 5to worship or serve. I am an exclusive God. I visit the consequences of parents’ sins on their descendants for three or four generations that hate me. 6I am kind to thousands who love me and obey me.

item.title: Exodus 21
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 21

1“Present these ordinances to the people. 2“If you buy a Hebrew slave, he’ll serve six years and go free on the seventh without pay. 3If he came alone, he’ll go out alone. If he has a wife, they’ll go out together. 4If his master gives him a wife and she bears him sons or daughters, the wife and her children belong to her master, and the slave will go out alone. 5But if the slave says he loves his master, his wife and children, and won’t leave them to be a free man, 6his master is to take him to the judges—to the door or doorpost—and pierce his ear with an awl. Then he’ll serve him permanently.

item.title: Exodus 22
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 22

1“If someone steals a cow or sheep, slaughters it or sells it, he has to pay five cows for one cow and four sheep for one sheep. 3bIf he doesn’t have anything, sell the thief for the theft. 4If what was stolen is found alive in the thief’s possession—cow, donkey, or sheep—the thief will pay double.

2If a thief gets caught breaking in at night and is struck and dies, the slayer won’t be held guilty of murder. 3aIf the theft happens during the day, the slayer will be guilty of murder. 5“If you overgraze a field or vineyard and let an animal loose that grazes in someone else’s field, you’ll pay compensation from the best of your own field and vineyard. 6“If your fire gets away from you and spreads to someone else’s thorn bushes, stacked grain, standing grain, or field, you’ll pay for damages.

item.title: Exodus 23
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 23

1“Don’t pass on false rumors, join sinners in giving malicious testimony, 2or follow the crowd in doing something bad. In a dispute, don’t join other people to pervert justice. 3Don’t be partial toward a poor person in a dispute. 4“If you run onto your enemy’s ox or donkey wandering around, return it. 5If you see a donkey that belongs to someone that hates you lying helpless under its load, free it.

item.title: Exodus 24
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 24

1Then the LORD told Moses, “Come up to me and worship at a distance—you, Aaron, Nadab, Abihu, and

the 70

elders. 2Yousg alone will approach me; the others and the community can’t approach me.”

3Moses recounted to the people the LORD’s ordinances, and they answered together, “We’ll do what he’s said.”

4Moses wrote them down. Then he got up early and built an altar at the foot of the mountain

item.title: Exodus 25
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 25

1The LORD said to him, 2“Tell the Israelites to take up an offering for me as their hearts move them: 3gold, silver, and bronze; 4blue, purple, and scarlet material; fine linen, goat hair, 5rams’ skins dyed red, dolphin skins, acacia wood, 6olive oil for lighting, spices for anointing oil and fragrant incense, 7onyx stones and setting stones for the ephod and pouch. 8Have them build a sanctuary so I can live among them. 9Build the Tabernacle and its furniture like I show you.

item.title: Exodus 26
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 26

1“Make the Tabernacle with 10 curtains of finely twined linen and blue, purple, and scarlet material. Make them with cherubs, a skilled weaver’s work. 2All the curtains will

be 42

x 6ft. 3Make 2 sets of 5 joined curtains. 4Make blue loops on the edge of the outer curtain in the first set; do the same with the second set. 5Make 50 loops in the one curtain, and 50 loops on the edge of the second set. Put the loops across from each other. 6Make 50 gold clasps and join the curtains together with them so the Tabernacle makes a unit. Ex 26:1-6 7-8“Make 11 curtains out of goats’ hair for a covering over the Tabernacle. Make them 45 x 6ft. 9Join 5 curtains in one set, and 6 curtains in another set. Double the sixth curtain at the front of the tent. 10Make 50 loops on the edge of the outside curtain in the two sets. 11Make 50 bronze clasps, put them into the loops, and join the tent together to make one unit. 12The overlapping part that’s left over in the curtains of the tent—the half curtain—will lap over the back of the Tabernacle. 13The 18ins on each side of what’s left over in the length of the curtain, will lap over the back of the sides of the Tabernacle to cover each side. 14Make a covering for the tent out of rams’ and dolphin skins dyed red. Ex 26:7-14 15“Make vertical boards out of acacia wood for the Tabernacle. 16Make them 15ft x 27in. 17With all the boards, make a mortise and tenon on each board, so they fit together. 18Make 20 boards for the south side of the Tabernacle. 19Make 40 silver bases under the 20 boards, 2 bases under each board for its mortise and tenon. 20-21Do the north side of the Tabernacle the same as the south side. 22For the back of the Tabernacle, the west end, make 6 boards. 23For the two back corners make 2 boards. 24They’ll double on top of each other; together they’ll be complete to the top to the first ring. Make both corners alike. 25There will be 8 boards with their 16 silver bases, 2 bases under each board. Ex 26:15-25 26“Make 5 braces out of acacia wood for the boards on one side of the Tabernacle, 275 braces for the boards on the other side, and 5 braces for the rear, west end. 28The middle brace in the center of the boards will go from one end to the other. 29Overlay the boards with gold and make their gold rings into holders for the braces. Overlay the braces with gold too. 30Build the Tabernacle by the plan I showed you on the mountain.” Ex 26:26-30 31“Make a curtain out of blue, purple, and scarlet material and finely twined linen. Put cherubs on it, a skilled weaver’s work. 32Hang it on four posts of acacia wood overlaid with gold, having gold hooks, and set on four silver sockets. 33Hang the curtain under the clasps and bring the Ark of Testimony inside the curtain that separates the Holy Place from the Holy of Holies. 34Mount the mercy seat on the Ark. 35Outside the curtain, set the table on the north side of the Tabernacle and the lampstand on the south side. 36For the doorway of the tent, make a screen out of blue, purple, and scarlet material and fine linen, a weaver’s work. 37For the screen, make five posts of acacia wood overlaid with gold, having gold hooks, and set on 5 bronze sockets. Ex 26:31-37 The Bronze Altar

item.title: Exodus 27
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 27

1“Make an altar out of acacia wood, 7½ x 7½ x 4½ft high 2with a horn on each corner. Make them one piece with the altar and overlaid with bronze. 3“Make bronze pails for removing the ashes, bronze shovels, basins, forks, and fire pans. 4“Make a network of bronze grating for it, and on the network put four bronze rings at the corners. 5Put the grating under the ledge of the altar so it reaches halfway up the altar. 6“For the altar make acacia poles overlaid with bronze. 7Insert the poles into the rings on the two sides of the altar for carrying it. 8Make it hollow with planks like you saw on the mountain.

item.title: Exodus 28
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 28

1“From the Israelites, have your brother Aaron and his sons Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar come to you to serve as priests. 2Make holy vestments for Aaron, glorious and beautiful. 3Talk to skilled artisans that I’ve given wisdom for making them and consecrate them for performing service to me. 4Make these vestments for Aaron and his sons: a pouch, ephod, robe, tunic made out of checkered work, a turban, and a sash. 5The artisans are to use gold; blue, purple, and scarlet material; and fine linen.

item.title: Exodus 29
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 29

1“This is how you’re to consecrate them as priests to me: take a young bull, two rams without blemish, 2bread without yeast, and cakes mixed with olive oil, wafers without yeast anointed with oil and made out of fine wheat flour. 3Put them in a basket and bring them with the bull and two rams. 4Take Aaron and his sons to the door and give them a bath. 5Put on Aaron the tunic, ephod robe, ephod, chest pouch, and skillfully woven band of the ephod. 6Put the turban on his head, and the holy crown on the turban. 7Then pour the anointing oil on his head. 8Put tunics on his sons. 9Put sashes around him and his sons and tie the caps on them. They’ll exercise the priesthood by permanent statute.

item.title: Exodus 30
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 30

1“Make an altar out of acacia wood as a place to burn incense: 218 x 18 x 36in with horns in one piece with it. 3Overlay it with pure gold on its sides, top, and horns; make a molding around it. 4On two sides put two gold rings under its molding on opposite ends for carrying it. 5Make the poles out of acacia wood overlaid with gold. 6Put the altar in front of the curtain that’s near the Ark of Testimony—in front of the mercy seat that’s on top of the Ark—where I’ll meet you. 7-8Aaron will burn fragrant incense on it every morning and evening and trim the lamps. Burn incense to me continuously throughout your generations. 9Don’t offer foreign incense, burnt offering, or meal offering on this altar. Don’t pour any liquid offering on it. 10Throughout your generations, Aaron will make atonement on its horns once a year with the blood of the sin offering. It’s most holy to me.

item.title: Exodus 32
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 32

1When Moses hadn’t come down from the mountain for a long time, the people gathered around Aaron and said, “Make us a god to go ahead of us. We don’t know what’s happened to this Moses that brought us out of Egypt.”

2Aaron said, “Take the gold earrings off of your wives, sons, and daughters, and bring them to me.” [3] 4He took them, and with a graving tool shaped a molten calf. They said, “This is your god, Israel, that brought you out of Egypt!”

item.title: Exodus 33
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 33

1The LORD told Moses, “Leave here and go to the land I swore I’d give the descendants of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. 2I’ll send an angel ahead of you to drive out the Canaanite, Amorite, Hittite, Perizzite, Hivite, and Jebusite. 3Go up to a land flowing with milk and honey. I won’t go up with you, because you’re stubborn, so I won’t destroy you on the way.”

item.title: Exodus 34
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 34

1The LORD told Moses, “Carve out two stone tablets like the first ones, and I’ll write on them what was on the tablets you shattered. 2Be ready by morning. Come up to the top of Mount Sinai and present yourself 3alone. Nobody can be on the mountain. Flocks and herds can’t graze by it.”

4He carved two stone tablets like the first ones, got up early, and took them up to Mount Sinai. 5The LORD came down in a cloud and stood there with him as he called on the LORD. 6He passed by Moses and proclaimed, “The LORD, the LORD God, merciful and gracious, slow to anger, abounding in kindness and faithfulness;7who shows kindness to thousands; forgives iniquity, transgression, and sin; yet doesn’t leave guilty people unpunished, and visits the consequences of parents’ sins on their descendants for three or four generations!”

item.title: Exodus 35
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 35

1Moses gathered the community and said, “The LORD has commanded these things: 2‘You can work for six days, but set the seventh day aside to him as a complete rest. Whoever works on it will be executed. 3Don’t start a fire in your houses on the Sabbath.’”

Ex 35:1-3

Materials for the Tabernacle

2Moses called Bezalel, Oholiab, and their artisans to begin the work. 3They received from him the contributions for building the sanctuary. [4] 5They told him, “The people are bringing more than we need.” 6He circulated a message throughout the camp that they didn’t need to contribute anything more. [7]

item.title: Exodus 37
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 37

1Bezalel made the Ark out of acacia wood: 45 x 27 x 27ins high. 2He overlaid it with pure gold inside and out, made a gold border around it, 3and

cast 4

gold rings for it, 2 on each side. 4He shaped poles out of acacia wood overlaid with gold 5and put them in the rings for carrying it.

6He formed a mercy seat out of pure gold: 45 x 27in. 7It

item.title: Exodus 38
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 38

1Then he built the altar for burnt offering out of acacia wood: 7½ x 7½ x 4½ft high. 2He formed horns on its four corners one piece with it and overlaid it with bronze. 3He made bronze utensils for the altar: pails, shovels, basins, meat hooks, and fire pans. 4He fashioned a bronze grating under the edge of the altar that reached halfway up, 5and

cast 4

rings for the 4 ends of the grating to hold the poles. 6He formed the poles out of acacia wood overlaid with bronze, 7and inserted them into the rings for carrying it. He made it hollow with planks. Basin for Washing

8He created the laver out of bronze with a bronze base, from the mirrors of the women that served at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting.

item.title: Exodus 39
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 39

1From the blue, purple, and scarlet material, they made finely woven vestments for Aaron to perform service in the Holy Place—like the LORD commanded Moses.

2He made the ephod out of gold; blue, purple, and scarlet material; and finely twined linen. 3They hammered out gold sheets and cut them into threads that were woven in with the blue, purple, and scarlet material; and the fine linen—an artisan’s work. 4They made attaching shoulder pieces for the ephod—attached at the two upper ends. 5The skillfully woven band on it had the same workmanship: gold; blue, purple, and scarlet material; and finely twined linen. 6They made the onyx stones, set in delicate gold ornamentation. They engraved the onyx stones like the engravings on a signet, showing the names of Israel’s sons. 7He placed them on the shoulder pieces of the ephod as memorial stones for them.

item.title: Exodus 40
item.description:
Exodus Chapter 40

1Then the LORD told Moses, 2“The first day, first month, set up the Tabernacle of the Tent of Meeting. 3Put the Ark of Testimony in it and screen it off with the curtain.

4Take the table in and arrange what goes on it; take the lampstand in and mount the lamps.

5Place the gold altar for incense in front of the Ark of Testimony, and set up the curtain across the door to the Tabernacle.
